titleStmt.title: An illustrated guide to landmarks in histological rat and mouse brain images

affiliation.note: Neural systems laboratory, University of Oslo, Norway
Neural systems laboratory, University of Oslo, Norway

analytic.title: An illustrated guide to landmarks in histological rat and mouse brain images

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: The brain is the most complex structure known, with large numbers of interconnected regions, subregions and zones.
The structural and functional architecture of brain regions differ across regions, and is often the focus of experimental studies in rat and mouse models for development, aging and disease.
The anatomical localization of neuroscientific data is thus crucial for interpretation of neuroscience data.
For histological images, efficient interpretation and analysis based on neuroanatomical information can be achieved by spatial registration of images to reference atlases (see, e.g.
Puchades et al., 2019, PLOS one; Yates et al., 2019, Front.
Neuroinf.).

However, accurate spatial registration critically depends on neuroanatomical knowledge, which is necessary to identify anatomical locations and determine the spatial location and orientation of histological images.
In this context, prominent and specific brain regions are highly useful and can be thought of as "landmark" structures that readily can be recognized in different images of brain tissue.
With this guide, we provide an overview of landmark structures in rat and mouse brains.
We have annotated a selection of coronal, sagittal, and horizontal images and provide descriptions of the illustrated landmark structures.
These landmarks provide a useful basis for getting an overview of murine brain anatomy in general and for spatial registration of brain images to reference atlases in particular.

The images used in this guide are taken from publicly available datasets downloaded from the EBRAINS infrastructure and the Allen Institute web portal, the references for which are listed below (click the headline to jump to the landmark descriptions):
-Coronal rat brain images o Leergaard, T. B., Lillehaug, S., Dale, A., & Bjaalie, J. G. (2018)

div.head: Landmarks in the coronal plane (anterior to posterior)

p.s: Landmark Description

div.head: Granular layers of the olfactory bulb

p.s: The most anterior section where the granular layer of the olfactory bulb is last seen (Figure 1, red)
The most anterior section where the corpus callosum is visible (Figure 1, green)
The most anterior section where the nucleus accumbens is visible (Figure 2, red)
The most anterior section where the striatum is visible (Figure 2, green)
The most anterior section in which the corpus callosum is continuous across the midline (Figure 3)
The most anterior section in which the anterior commissure is continuous across the midline (Figure 4)
The most anterior section where the hippocampus can be distinguished (Figure 5).
The rest of the anterior part of the hippocampus has a characteristic profile and is well suited to determine anteroposterior location
A triangle shaped nuclei compilation that can be seen through many sections medially in the brain going anterior to posterior (Figure 6)
The development of the optic chiasm into optic tract, and the change in shape of optic tract when moving posteriorly (Figure 7, red)
The most posterior section where habenular nuclei develops into habenular commissure (Figure 8, red)
Most anterior section where posterior commissure appears dorsally to 3rd ventricle (Figure 9)
The most anterior section where the corpus callosum is no longer continuous across the midline (Figure 10) Note that in transgenic mice, an asymmetry with the template is often observed
The most anterior section where ventral dentate gyrus is visible (Figure 11)
The most anterior section where the nucleus is still visible (Figure 12)
The most anterior section in which the thalamus is no longer visible (Figure 13)
The most posterior section showing the posterior superior colliculus (Figure 14)
The most posterior section showing the dentate gyrus (Figure 15)
The most posterior section showing the posterior subiculum (Figure 16)
The most anterior section in which the superior colliculus is no longer visible and the inferior colliculus occupies the dorsal-most part of the brain stem (Figure 17)
The most anterior section in which the grey matter of the pontine nuclei can be discerned among the distinct transverse fibres of the pons (Figure 18)

div.head: Separation of inferior colliculus and brainstem

p.s: The first section posteriorly where the inferior colliculus has separated from the brainstem and cerebellum in visible medially (Figure 19)
The most posterior section where the tissue of inferior colliculus is still visible (Figure 19)
The section where facial nerve is seen across the whole brainstem (Figure 20)
The most anterior and posterior sections after the separation of brainstem and cerebellum in which the nuclei are visible (Figure 21)
The first section posteriorly where cerebellum and brainstem are no longer connected (Figure 22)
The last section where tissue of cerebellum is still visible (Figure 23).
Note that this should only be used carefully in the case of physical sections, as small parts of the posterior cerebellum might have been lost during mounting.

div.head: Inferior olive, anterior and posterior end

p.s: The most anterior and the most posterior sections in which the inferior olive is visible (Figure 24 and 26, respectively)

div.head: Merging of tissue around central canal

p.s: The section where the tissue by the 4th ventricle closes and the central canal is created (Figure 25)
The first lateral section where the hippocampus is visible (Figure 1)
The first lateral section where the striatum is visible (Figure 2)
The first lateral section where cerebellar tissue becomes visible (Figure 3)
The first lateral section where the internal capsule is visible (Figure 4)
The first lateral section where the globus pallidus, external segment is visible (Figure 5)
The section where the cell layer of CA3 forms an x between the dorsal and ventral hippocampus (Figure 6, green)
The most lateral section where the brainstem is visible (Figure 6, red)
The most lateral section where the cerebellar nuclei is visible (Figure 7)
Ventral geniculate nucleus The first section where the ventral geniculate nucleus (thalamus) is visible (Figure 8)

div.head: Separation of dorsal and ventral hippocampus

p.s: The most lateral section where the whole hippocampus is divided into a dorsal and a ventral part (Figure 9)

div.head: Separation of dorsal and ventral parahippocampal region

p.s: The first section where the parahippocampal region separates into dorsal and ventral parts (Figure 10)
The most lateral section where the brachium is visible ventrally to the para-and presubiculum (Figure 11, red)
The most lateral section where the olfactory tubercle is visible in the ventral part of the hemisphere (Figure 11, green)
The most lateral section where the olfactory bulb becomes visible (Figure 12)
The most medial section where the ventral end of the hippocampus is still visible (Figure 13)
The most lateral section where the nuclei first is visible (Figure 14)
The section where the merging of anterior and posterior part of the anterior commissure is visible (Figure 15)
The first section where the striatum is completely gone and all that is visible is the septal nucleus (Figure 16)
The most medial section where the striatum is still visible (Figure 17)
Medial dorsal hippocampus The most medial section where the end of the dorsal hippocampus is still visible (Figure 18)
The most medial section where the tissue of the inferior colliculus is still visible (Figure 19)
The medial section where the nucleus becomes visible on top of the round shaped thalamic nuclei (Figure 20)
The most dorsal section where the superior colliculus is visible (Figure 1, red)
The most dorsal section where the inferior colliculus is visible (Figure 1, green)
The most dorsal section where the hippocampus is visible (Figure 2)
The most dorsal section where the cerebellar tissue is visible (Figure 3)
The most dorsal section where the corpus callosum merges across the middle (Figure 4).
Also, more laterally, the shape of the anterior part of the corpus callosum may assist in the anchoring process
The most dorsal section where the striatum is visible (Figure 5)
The most dorsal section where the fasciola cinereum is visible as two long parallel bands of cells medially in the brain (Figure 6)
The first section where dorsal fornix is replaced with the septal nuclei (Figure 7)

div.head: Separation of medial and lateral dentate gyrus

p.s: The most dorsal section where the dentate gyrus separates into a medial and lateral part (Figure 8)
The most dorsal section where the thalamic nuclei becomes visible between the medial and lateral dentate (Figure 8)
The most dorsal section where the tissue of the olfactory bulb is visible (Figure 9)

div.head: Merging of 3rd ventricle and lateral ventricle

p.s: The most dorsal section where the two ventricles merge (Figure 10)
The most dorsal section where the cerebellar nuclei are visible in the deep cerebral white matter of the cerebellum (Figure 11)
The most dorsal section where the globus pallidus is visible (Figure 12)
The most dorsal section where the anterior commissure is conjoined across the midline in the anterior region of the brain (Figure 13)

div.head: Separation of the midline of anterior commissure

p.s: The most dorsal section where the anterior commissure is divided into left and right parts (Figure 14)
The most dorsal section where the cerebellar tissue is replaced by brainstem tissue and the 4th ventricle is prominent (Figure 15)
The most ventral section where the striatum is clearly visible (Figure 16)
The most ventral section where the cerebellar tissue is visible (Figure 17)
The most dorsal section where a clear band of cells of the piriform cortex is visible along the lateral part of each hemisphere (Figure 18)

div.head: Separation of brainstem and ventral cortex

p.s: The most dorsal section where the brainstem and the ventral part of the cortex separate (Figure 19)
The most ventral section where the layers of the olfactory bulb are still visible (Figure 20)
The most ventral section where the hippocampal formation is still visible (Figure 21)
The most dorsal section where the optic chiasm becomes a band across the anterior part of the brain (Figure 22)
The most dorsal section where the nuclei is seen anteriorly in the brain stem (Figure 23)
Figure 1: Cell layers of olfactory bulb (red) / Anterior corpus callosum (green)
Figure 1: Lateral hippocampus
Figure 1: Superior colliculus (red) / Inferior colliculus (green)
